title.narrative: Amphibian Program-International Grants

description.narrative: The role of the North American bullfrog in spreading chytridiomycosis across endangered frog.populations in the Atlantic Forest of Brazil

participating-org.narrative: Regents of the University of Michigan

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

receiver-org.narrative: Regents of the University of Michigan

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Wildlife Without Borders-Amphibians In Decline

description.narrative: "AD-0137: The role of the North American bullfrog in spreading chytridiomycosis across endangered frog populations in the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. In partnership with University of Michigan, this project will support a conservation effort for multiple amphibian species in the Atlantic Forest of Brazil, by determining the prevalence of chytrid fungus infection among six endangered frog species in relation to the abundance of the non-native American bullfrog (Lithobates catesbeianus). .Specific activities include: (1) field surveys at five Atlantic Forest sites to determine the abundance of American bullfrogs; (2) field surveys of chytrid fungus prevalence among focal endangered species; (3) DNA sequence analysis of the chytrid fungus detected at the survey sites to determine the relative distribution and frequency of different chytrid genotypes; and (4) outreach to government personnel and other key stakeholders to inform them of the presence of chytrid fungus in the Atlantic forest, the association between chytrid, bullfrog farms, and escaped bullfrogs, and to discuss mitigation measures."

title.narrative: Conservation of the Critically Endangered Araripe Manakin

description.narrative: This project will improve the conservation status of the Araripe Manakin. Specific objectives include: (1) Advancement of the creation of at least three additional RPPNs within the habitat of the Araripe Manakin; (2) Reforestation of habitat within the range of the Araripe Manakin.

description.narrative: This project will focus on making an accurate assessment of Red Knot seasonal abundance and habitat use in eastern Cear. This project will also support the development of new partnerships to develop a long-term strategy for creating and sustaining a large-scale shorebird research and monitoring program in northeastern Brazil.

title.narrative: SHRIMP AQUACULT. BRAZIL

description.narrative: This project seeks to increase understanding of contaminant exposure that shorebirds may experience at commercial shrimp farms during migration and wintering periods in northeastern Brazil, leading to the development of best management practices that reduce exposure. Ultimately, this will lead to solutions that incorporate shorebird conservation needs into shrimp aquaculture permitting processes, promote sustainable shrimp aquaculture development and alleviate competition between conservation and economic priorities. Birds that will benefit include red knot, semipalmated sandpiper, lesser and greater yellowlegs, short-billed dowitcher, ruddy turnstone, black-bellied plover, willet, and whimbrel...

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

receiver-org.narrative: New Jersey Audubon Society

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: MIGRATORY BIRDS IN THE CERRADO: EDUCATIO

description.narrative: The project's main goal is to increase the number of Brazilians who are concerned with conservation and understand the importance of conserving the Cerrado region, as well as the migratory birds that winter there. The partners plan to use two approaches: communication using literature and media (radio programs) and education through the training of teachers in the public school system to mobilize them for the conservation of these bird species and the remaining areas of the Cerrado in the region. They plan to reach different target audiences with different methodologies. For children, they will produce stories that strengthen their ties to these species of birds. For the general population, they will generate radio programs that creatively deal with these issues. Students in the public school system from 10 to18 years will be reached by the action of teachers trained with tools of art, methodological strategies and awareness. The products previewed in this project, such as books, radio programs and educational material produced by teachers, can be applied in other areas of the Cerrado in Brazil. Thus, this project can start to reverse the reduction in the availability of wintering grounds for species that depend on the Cerrado domain.

participating-org.narrative: Fundao de Apoio Institucional ao Desenvolvimento Cientfico e Tecnolgico

title.narrative: SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION IN LAGOA DO PEIXE

description.narrative: Partners will address key conservation knowledge gaps and empower proactive conservation planning and action by (1) mapping critical habitat for five shorebird species on Brazil's coast focusing on Red knot (a threatened subspecies) and compare to mapping in 1980's to determine habitat loss, (2) identify habitats lost to development and those most threatened by housing development, agriculture and forestry expansion, recreational use, off road vehicle use, wind power turbines and aquaculture, (3) overlay them on shorebird mapping to develop most at risk habitat locations, and (4) translating all products into Portuguese and introducing the product to key Brazilian biologists and conservation policy specialists.

participating-org.narrative: Conserve Wildlife Foundation of New Jersey

title.narrative: Conservation of the leatherback turtle nesting populations in Espirito Santo, Brazil,

description.narrative: (1) analyse satellite tracking data in support of an MPA; (2) conduct training of field monitors to improve capacity for data collection and nest protection; (3) characterize fisheries and fishing activities; (4) conduct beach patrols to tag nesting females and monitor nests; and (5) promote outreach and education activities including night patrols on nesting beaches with local community members.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION FACE TO THE PANDEMIC: ACTIONS NEEDED IN NESTING GROUNDS OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWKSBILL AND LEATHERBACK SEA TURTLES IN BRAZIL

description.narrative: This project will be key for the hawksbill and leatherback turtle nesting populations in Brazil. It will promote conservation actions and also support the development of highly needed data analyses to help to improve the conservation of these Critically Endangered populations by answering ecological questions through research collaboration and publication of scientific evidence.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION FACE TO THE PANDEMIC: ACTIONS NEEDED IN NESTING GROUNDS OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWKSBILL AND LEATHERBACK SEA TURTLES IN BRAZIL

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE HAWKSBILL AND LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATIONS IN BRAZIL. THE RECIPIENT WILL 1. CONDUCT STANDARDIZED NESTING SURVEYS TO COUNT AND PROTECT HAWKBILL NESTS ON 42 KM OF THE PRIMARY HAWKSBILL NESTING BEACHES IN BRAZIL AND 2. CONDUCT OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND TOURISTS AND 3. ANALYZE STABLE ISOTOPE, SATELLITED TELEMETRY, AND NESTING BEACH TEMPERATURE DATA COLLECTED TO INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FOR THE SMALL AND HIGHLY ENDANGERED LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION.

title.narrative: SAFEGUARDING WINTERING HABITAT FOR RUFA

description.narrative: The northwestern coastline of Brazil hosts millions of shorebirds, having been identified as the third most important area for wintering shorebirds in South America including rufa Red Knot, Whimbrel, and Semipalmated Sandpiper. This area is also highlighted as the primary wintering area for the 'North Coast of South America' Recovery Unit of rufa Red Knot. Multiple protected areas have been designated along this coastline, but most are in management categories with the least restrictions on use (e.g. extractive reserves, environmental protection areas) and have limited active enforcement or shorebird-specific management. Furthermore, with an expanding space flight launch site, the development of new ports, and the potential installation of wind energy facilities, shrimp farms and oil exploration, it is essential to better understand and safeguard the critical habitats for shorebirds in this region. The project will compile existing data to identify, delimit, and prioritize key areas for safeguarding and enhanced management. An aerial survey with a Red Knot specific protocol and increased International Shorebird Survey monitoring will add to the existing data to better understand the current status of shorebirds in the states of Para and Maranho. With the critical sites better defined, a stakeholder engagement process will be undertaken to define existing management structures, assess threats, identify opportunities for conservation action, and make recommendations regarding integrating shorebird needs within protected area management plans.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: ENSURING CONSERVATION OF REMNANT POPULATIONS OF HOGE S SIDE-NECKED TURTLE (MESOCLEMMYS HOGEI) IN THE ONLY PROTECTED AREA FOR THE SPECIES IN SOUTHEASTERN BRAZIL AND SURROUNDING AREAS

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter threats of habitat degradation and fisheries bycatch and ensure the survival of remnant.populations. This species is the most endangered turtle in Brazil, where it is endemic. Activities include: (1) developing a.management plan and habitat restoration program for the Ninho da Tartaruga Reserve;(2) initiating a population monitoring.program in the reserve; (3) constructing a nursery to provide native plants to restore streambank habitat for this species; (4).establishing a hook replacement program with local fishers (from common J hooks to circle hooks which are less damaging to.accidentally captured turtles); and (5) initiating surveys in areas near the reserve to locate other potential remnant populations.
